title: The Input Scroll
subtitle: Getting User Input & Working with Strings
description:
# The Input Scroll: Interactive Programs

**Note:** In real Godot games, user input comes from keyboard/mouse events. This lesson teaches the concept using simulated console input.

## String Operations

Strings are text values with powerful methods:

**Concatenation (joining):**
```gdscript
var greeting = "Hello " + "World"
print(greeting)  # Hello World
```

**String formatting:**
```gdscript
var name = "Knight"
var level = 5
var message = "Name: %s, Level: %d" % [name, level]
print(message)  # Name: Knight, Level: 5
```

**String methods:**
```gdscript
var text = "GODOT"
print(text.to_lower())  # godot
print(text.length())    # 5
print(text.substr(0, 3))  # GOD
```

## Your Quest

Work with strings to create character profiles:

1. Create variables for name, class, and level
2. Combine them into a formatted message
3. Use string methods to manipulate text
4. Print a complete character card

solutionCode:
# Create character variables
var hero_name = "Warrior"
var hero_class = "KNIGHT"
var hero_level = 10

# Create a greeting message by combining strings
var greeting = "Welcome, " + hero_name + "!"
print(greeting)

# Convert hero_class to lowercase
var class_lower = hero_class.to_lower()
print("Class: ", class_lower)

# Create a formatted character card
var card = "=== Character Card ===\nName: %s\nClass: %s\nLevel: %d" % [hero_name, class_lower, hero_level]
print(card)
hints: Use %s for strings and %d for numbers in formatting
\n creates a new line in strings
